unnormalised: A new study published in "The Lancet Gastroenterology & Hepatology" highlights the increasing cases of GERD, i.e. Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease, amongst young adults in metros like Mumbai & Delhi. Dr. Rajesh Sharma from AIIMS, New Delhi, one of the co-authors, said, "We're seeing more patients, especially those aged 25-35, complaining of acidity & heartburn." He suspects lifestyle factors like late-night work & spicy food are to blame.
normalised: A new study published in "The Lancet Gastroenterology and Hepatology" highlights the increasing cases of G-E-R-D, that is Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease, amongst young adults in metros like Mumbai and Delhi. Doctor Rajesh Sharma from A-I-I-M-S, New Delhi, one of the co-authors, said, "We are seeing more patients, especially those aged twenty five to thirty five, complaining of acidity and heartburn." He suspects lifestyle factors like late-night work and spicy food are to blame.

unnormalised: The study, which surveyed 1,500 individuals across 5 Indian cities, found that nearly 30% reported experiencing GERD symptoms at least twice a week. Alarmingly, many self-medicated with over-the-counter antacids like Gelusil or Digene, ignoring the potential for long-term complications. "People think it's just acidity, but untreated GERD can lead to serious issues like Barrett's esophagus or even esophageal cancer," warned Dr. Sharma.

Alarmingly, many self-medicated with over-the-counter antacids like Gelusil or Digene, ignoring the potential for long-term complications. "People think it's just acidity, but untreated G-E-R-D can lead to serious issues like Barrett's esophagus or even esophageal cancer," warned Doctor Sharma.

unnormalised: Experts recommend lifestyle changes such as avoiding large meals before bed, elevating the head while sleeping, and reducing consumption of oily & spicy foods. In severe cases, medications like PPIs (Proton Pump Inhibitors) may be prescribed by a gastroenterologist after proper diagnosis & evaluation, typically after tests such as an endoscopy (Rs. 3000-Rs. 6000 at a private clinic).

unnormalised: The Indian Society of Gastroenterology (ISG) is planning a national awareness campaign to educate the public about GERD & its prevention. They aim to reach out through social media & community health programs. "We need to make people aware that persistent acidity is not normal and requires proper medical attention," said a spokesperson for the ISG. A detailed report will be released on 15/08/2024.
